The CEO Blindspot
 
When it comes to understanding what employees want and need from their jobs and the real-world challenges they’re facing, there is a chasm between what the C-suite thinks and the reality of what employees actually experience.
This disconnect has a direct impact on an employers’ ability to attract and retain talent, which is why it’s imperative that the C-suite and senior leaders not make decisions without consulting their people data first.

subject: Lessons For All Leaders
body:
Julia Boorstin was 13 when her mother told her that, by the time she grew up, women could be just as powerful as men: “captains of industry, running the biggest companies.” 
 
Counterintuitive and Important Lessons for all Leaders
 
TODAY, February 22, at 12 p.m ET
 
Julia Boorstin was 13 when her mother told her that, by the time she grew up, women could be just as powerful as men: “captains of industry, running the biggest companies.” Unfortunately, when it comes to gender equity, conditions have not changed as much as her mother had hoped. But female leaders all over the world are succeeding, not in spite of but because of their unique strengths and personality traits. They’re defying the odds. What can we learn from them?
In “When Women Lead: What They Achieve, Why They Succeed, and How We Can Learn from Them,” Boorstin, TV reporter and creator of CNBC’s Disruptor 50 franchise, shares her groundbreaking and deeply reported narrative work incorporating the stories of hundreds of female executives. It reveals the counterintuitive, against-all-odds approaches of women running the world’s most innovative (and successful) companies — and what we can learn from them.
Whether you’re a woman looking to rise in your organization or taking on a new leadership position or a male leader looking to empower women in your organization, “When Women Lead” is a radical blueprint for the future of business.
In this webinar you will:
Learn about the commonalities of female executives who defied odds and explore the research that shows that a more varied and counterintuitive set of leadership qualities yields better results regardless of gender.
Learn how three specific leadership traits significantly contribute to the success of anyone, regardless of industry or position — particularly in turbulent, tumultuous and challenging times.
Walk away with insights that will help you influence, reaffirm or reassess your talent management strategy in your organization.
REGISTER NOW

subject: Tips for Creating a Lasting DEI Culture
body:
A DEI culture leads to better-run companies with a stronger bottom line, as well as a more motivated workforce.
 
 
WORKPLACE FAIRNESS
 
 
Tips for Creating a Lasting DEI Culture
Creating a lasting DEI culture requires everyone from top to bottom in an organization to embrace the idea that representation is critical to success in the modern business world. An engaged workforce that feels their voices are heard can help companies resolve issues using a wide variety of perspectives.
FEATURED PARTNER
 
 
Comcast NBCUniversal Honors Black Changemakers
Comcast NBCUniversal honors Black changemakers to celebrate Black History Month, highlighting content and talent from their platform. “Black innovation has and continues to forge a path forward in American society through creativity and imagination for a better tomorrow,” Comast said.
UPCOMING WEBINAR
 
 
Mar. 22, 2023 | The Impact of Workplace Trauma and How to Heal from It
In this session, DiversityInc will talk with experts who have dealt with workplace trauma firsthand and discuss ways to heal from it as well as ways to prevent it through improved workplace practices.

How Companies Are Celebrating Black History Month
Black History Month started at the beginning of February and goes until March 1, serving as a time to celebrate the history, culture and resilience of Black people in the United States. 
In this article, we’ll look at how organizations are celebrating Black History Month and helping to elevate the voices of Black Americans.

Today at 11 a.m. ET
 
C
hief Learning Officer’s Breakfast Club event, "A Marathon, Not a Sprint: Examining the DEI Journey," is today!
 
Over the past several years, particularly in North America, there has been a more widespread awakening to the many inequities and inequalities present in all areas of society, including our workplaces. In 2020, many organizations pledged a stronger commitment to DEI efforts and establishing an inclusive workplace culture. But these aren't simple endeavors, and there are no quick solutions.
 
In 2023, three years after the murder of George Floyd sparked a social justice movement, where is your organization along this journey, and what role does L&D play in your DEI strategy?

subject: Owning the Leadership Role: Learning Leaders' Expanding Skillsets
body:
The upheaval and challenges of the pandemic, the move to hybrid work and the push for big upskilling and internal mobility initiatives have finally given L&D leaders the seat at the table they've long been seeking.
View in browser
 
 
Owning the Leadership Role: Learning Leaders' Expanding Skillsets
 
Wednesday, March 29, at 11 a.m. ET
 
On Wednesday, March 29, Chief Learning Officer (CLO) will host its next Breakfast Club, continuing its work in connecting leaders over breakfast to strengthen the link between learning and development and business strategy.
The upheaval and challenges of the pandemic, the move to hybrid work and the push for big upskilling and internal mobility initiatives have finally given L&D leaders the seat at the table they've long been seeking. They are being tasked with larger, more complicated strategic challenges, and this requires them to develop their own personal skills in some areas alongside their more traditional L&D skills, particularly data and decision-making, leadership, core business skills and more, according to 2022 RedThread research, "
Future-proofing L&D: Developing the Right Skills
."
 
With expanding responsibilities and the pressure to deliver results, how are L&D leaders prioritizing their own skills development and the development of their L&D teams?
Each mini-event lasts about two hours and consists of a 60-minute panel discussion with L&D and talent practitioners, a 20-minute FASTtalk presentation and a 20-minute research segment, garnering real-time data from attendees and prompting discussion of the day’s themes, followed by closing remarks from me, CLO’s editor-in-chief.
 
We hope that you can join us.
 
Sincerely,
Ashley St. John
Founder, Chief Content Officer & Editor-in-Chief
BetterWork Media Group, parent company of Chief Learning Officer & Talent Management

subject: 6 Essential Skills Your Team Needs To Succeed
body:
At Section4, we've partnered with more than 150 companies to develop and retain high performers. 
 
6 Essential Skills Your Team Needs To Succeed
 
Thursday, March 30, at 12 p.m ET
 
At Section4, we've partnered with more than 150 companies to develop and retain high performers. We've found that successful learning and development programs share one characteristic: FOCUS. When employees are presented with too many courses, they simply don't engage with them. Completion rates are low and business impact is zero. Instead, we recommend focusing on 5–10 skills that are essential to your company's success.
But what should those skills be?
We surveyed 10,000 high performers to find out what they want to learn in 2023, and in this webinar we reveal what they said.
Learning Outcomes:
The six skills that high performers say they need to be successful.
How to get current and future high performers (your busiest employees) to engage in learning.
Why transforming ICs and managers into high performers has outsized impact and ROI for your business.

subject: Meet the 2023 Catalyst Award Winners
body:
Learn from The Hartford and UPMC at Catalyst Awards on March 30. 
You're receiving this email because you subscribed to receive Catalyst emails. You can opt-out by clicking “Update Profile” at the bottom of this email. 
 
 
 
 
 
REGISTER FOR THE 2023 CATALYST AWARDS
 
 
“The Catalyst Award-winning initiatives from The Hartford and UPMC are testaments to what is possible when DEI is prioritized at every level. With intentionality, commitment, and innovation, these initiatives are accelerating equity and serving as models for others to do the same.”
 
—Lorraine Hariton, Catalyst President & CEO  
 
Ashton
,
Last month, 
Catalyst announced
 that 
initiatives at The Hartford and UPMC
 (University of Pittsburgh Medical Center) had won the 2023 Catalyst Award—the premier recognition of organizational diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives that drive representation and inclusion for women. 
The Hartford and UPMC join a roster of 108 initiatives across 96 organizations that have won the Catalyst Award since 1987.  
How did they do it?  
Learn more by attending the 
2023 Catalyst Awards Conference & Dinner
 on Thursday, March 30. You’ll hear directly from the senior leaders of both companies while networking with hundreds of other global corporate leaders who are committed to advancing gender equity at work.  
The event’s theme, 
Accelerating Equity on All Fronts—So Women Thrive
, urges leaders to build more gender-equitable workplaces from the frontlines to the C-suite.  
Tickets are sold separately for the in-person (NYC) and online Conference and the in-person Dinner. Register today and learn how your company can become part of the Catalyst Award-winning community!  
 
REGISTER FOR THE 2023 CATALYST AWARDS
 
 
 
 
 
 
In case you missed it, 
you can also learn how to apply for the 2024 Catalyst Award directly from Catalyst Award Chair Jennifer Thorpe-Moscon, PhD. 
Watch our recent webinar outlining the process and requirements.  
 
LEARN HOW TO APPLY FOR THE 2024 CATALYST AWARD
 
 
 
 
 
 
In a recent interview for the 
Leaders Who Care video series
, Catalyst President & CEO Lorraine Hariton shared stories of two powerful women mentors in her life—her mother and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton—who have shaped her leadership journey. Hariton was interviewed by Mark Sadovnick, Managing Partner of 5th Element Group.  
 
WATCH THE INTERVIEW (LENGTH: 5 MIN.)
 
 
 
 
 
 
Don't Miss These Additional Upcoming Events
February 15 | Webinar 
Allyship in the Workplace: Leadership Practices That Support Career Advancement for Black Women
During Black History Month, celebrated in February in the United States and Canada, join this conversation on effective sponsorship and how allies can help to break down systemic barriers that impede Black women’s career progress. 
 
February 22 | EMEA Roundtable | Virtual 
Unpacking Menopause in the Workplace
 
Learn about the effect and stigma of menopause, how it impacts women in the workplace, and how organisations can build a successful menopause strategy—from normalising the conversation to integrating it into other DEI programmes.  
 
February 23 | Partner Event | Virtual

subject: Want to Be a More Equitable And Inclusive Leader?
body:
Plus resources to recognize Black History Month and more.
 
FEBRUARY 2023
RESEARCH
 | 
EVENTS
 | 
BLOG
 | 
SUBSCRIBE
 
 
 
Want to Be a More Equitable And 
﻿Inclusive Leader?
Dear 
Ashton
,
As we begin Black History Month in the US and Canada and LGBT History Month in the UK, I am reflecting on how we can all lead for equity and inclusion.
It has been a difficult start to the year 2023. In recent weeks in the United States, we’ve seen the death of Tyre Nichols, a Black man, after a traffic stop in Memphis, Tennessee; a mass shooting targeting members of the AANHPI community celebrating Lunar New Year in Monterey Bay Park, California; and incidents of workplace violence and mass shootings in Half Moon Bay, California—all against a backdrop of rising antisemitism; the Woman, Life, Freedom movement in Iran; and other global conflicts. As we work alongside one another and lead teams, we must acknowledge how collective crises impact how people might show up—and do so with empathy, grace, and humanity. 
Read my full statement
 on the Catalyst website.  
There are many ways that leaders can create more equitable and empathic workplaces. In Catalyst’s most-recent 
CEO Champions For Change report
, we were happy to share that our cohort of 70+ global CEOs—who have pledged to advance more Black women and other women of color into leadership roles—are outpacing their global peers across metrics of representation, pay equity, and board accountability. 
But more leaders need to step up and address inequities in their own companies.
Here's how: First, educate yourself on the prevalence of racism in the workplace globally. A 
new Catalyst exposé
 finds that 51% of women from marginalized racial and ethnic groups 
have experienced racism
 
in their current workplace
. The numbers are even higher for women with darker skin tones, queer women, and transgender women. Many of those we interviewed shared disturbing incidents of both overt and covert racism.
Second, create an action plan for change. Attend our 
February 15 webinar
, 
Allyship in the Workplace: Leadership Practices That Support Career Advancement for Black Women, 
featuring leaders from Catalyst and Medtronic. Get 
expert tips from Uber and Ulta Beauty
 
in our new Supporter-exclusive Practice, 
Forging Career Pathways for People from Marginalized Racial and Ethnic Groups
. And join us on Thursday, March 30 at our 
premier annual event
, the 2023 Catalyst Awards, to learn from hundreds of global leaders committed to 
Accelerating Equity on All Fronts—So Women Thrive
.
Finally, no matter where you are on your DEI journey, you must measure your progress. True commitment to equity means holding ourselves accountable to concrete, measurable goals. Our 
comprehensive measurement tool
, 
Beginning a Measurement Process
, walks you through some of the most important metrics to track and how.
Find more resources in our 
Accelerating Equity on All Fronts resource hub
. And become a more equitable and inclusive leader today.
 
 
 
Lorraine Hariton
﻿
Catalyst President & CEO
 
 
 
Next Month: Join Catalyst to Celebrate Women's History Month and International Women's Day
Inclusion is no longer a nice-to-have, optional element in the workplace. It’s imperative. Clients, customers, and employees both expect and demand it. During Women’s History Month (observed in March in the United States, United Kingdom, and Australia), and International Women’s Day (March 8), join us to celebrate the individuals and organizations who 
#EmbraceEquity
 and create cultures where 
#InclusionThrives
. 
 
JOIN THE CAMPAIGN

subject: Three Traits of Successful Leaders
body:
Julia Boorstin was 13 when her mother told her that, by the time she grew up, women could be just as powerful as men: “captains of industry, running the biggest companies.” 
 
Counterintuitive and Important Lessons for all Leaders
 
Wednesday, February 22, at 12 p.m ET
 
Julia Boorstin was 13 when her mother told her that, by the time she grew up, women could be just as powerful as men: “captains of industry, running the biggest companies.” Unfortunately, when it comes to gender equity, conditions have not changed as much as her mother had hoped. But female leaders all over the world are succeeding, not in spite of but because of their unique strengths and personality traits. They’re defying the odds. What can we learn from them?
In “When Women Lead: What They Achieve, Why They Succeed, and How We Can Learn from Them,” Boorstin, TV reporter and creator of CNBC’s Disruptor 50 franchise, shares her groundbreaking and deeply reported narrative work incorporating the stories of hundreds of female executives. It reveals the counterintuitive, against-all-odds approaches of women running the world’s most innovative (and successful) companies — and what we can learn from them.
Whether you’re a woman looking to rise in your organization or taking on a new leadership position or a male leader looking to empower women in your organization, “When Women Lead” is a radical blueprint for the future of business.
In this webinar you will:
Learn about the commonalities of female executives who defied odds and explore the research that shows that a more varied and counterintuitive set of leadership qualities yields better results regardless of gender.
Learn how three specific leadership traits significantly contribute to the success of anyone, regardless of industry or position — particularly in turbulent, tumultuous and challenging times.
Walk away with insights that will help you influence, reaffirm or reassess your talent management strategy in your organization.
REGISTER NOW

subject: The Role of Credit in the Black Homeownership Gap
body:
At its high in 2004, Black homeownership peaked at 49.7%, trailing well behind the record 76.2% homeownership rate for white people.
 
 
RECENT NEWS
 
 
The Role of Credit in the Black Homeownership Gap
For 246 years, the damaging institution of slavery categorized Black men, women and children as property and wealth, not people. More than a century and a half after being granted their freedom, Black people are struggling to build wealth as homeowners. 
FEATURED PARTNER
 
 
Medtronic Advances Health Equity With Zero Health Gaps Pledge
Medtronic is joining the Global Health Equity Network to help advance health equity, kicking off its commitment by signing the Zero Health Gaps Pledge. The Global Health Equity Network is a World Economic Forum initiative that helps mobilize the private and public sectors to make changes in the current state of health equity. 
UPCOMING WEBINAR

Jason Marshall entered a career in law enforcement as bright-eyed and bushy-tailed as any new recruit ready to change the world. But like so many others, the reality was that the world had changed him after just a couple of years.

subject: Insights to Influence Your Talent Management Strategy
body:
Julia Boorstin was 13 when her mother told her that, by the time she grew up, women could be just as powerful as men: “captains of industry, running the biggest companies.” 
 
Counterintuitive and Important Lessons for all Leaders
 
Wednesday, February 22, at 12 p.m ET
 
Julia Boorstin was 13 when her mother told her that, by the time she grew up, women could be just as powerful as men: “captains of industry, running the biggest companies.” Unfortunately, when it comes to gender equity, conditions have not changed as much as her mother had hoped. But female leaders all over the world are succeeding, not in spite of but because of their unique strengths and personality traits. They’re defying the odds. What can we learn from them?
In “When Women Lead: What They Achieve, Why They Succeed, and How We Can Learn from Them,” Boorstin, TV reporter and creator of CNBC’s Disruptor 50 franchise, shares her groundbreaking and deeply reported narrative work incorporating the stories of hundreds of female executives. It reveals the counterintuitive, against-all-odds approaches of women running the world’s most innovative (and successful) companies — and what we can learn from them.
Whether you’re a woman looking to rise in your organization or taking on a new leadership position or a male leader looking to empower women in your organization, “When Women Lead” is a radical blueprint for the future of business.
In this webinar you will:
Learn about the commonalities of female executives who defied odds and explore the research that shows that a more varied and counterintuitive set of leadership qualities yields better results regardless of gender.
Learn how three specific leadership traits significantly contribute to the success of anyone, regardless of industry or position — particularly in turbulent, tumultuous and challenging times.
Walk away with insights that will help you influence, reaffirm or reassess your talent management strategy in your organization.

subject: Creating a Fair Workplace While Prioritizing Health Equity
body:
Employers are responsible for creating and upholding health equity, which starts with building trust.
 
 
RECENT NEWS
 
 
Creating a Fair Workplace While Prioritizing Health Equity
Employers are responsible for creating and upholding health equity and it starts with building trust. That was the message from DiversityInc CEO Carolynn L. Johnson as she moderated a panel titled “Building a Diverse Healthcare Workforce: Best Practices for Recruiting, Hiring & Promoting Professionals of Color” at the Center for Healthcare Innovation’s Diversity, Inclusion and Health Equity Symposium in New York City last week. 
EDUCATION
 
 
Career Transition: How The PhD Project Helped Jason Marshall Move from Law Enforcement to Academia
Jason Marshall entered a career in law enforcement as bright-eyed and bushy-tailed as any new recruit ready to change the world. But like so many others, the reality was that the world had changed him after just a couple of years.
FEATURED PARTNER
 
 
Dow's Paul Kline on Invigorating the Future of STEM
Dow sponsors For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology (FIRST), which is a robotics community that encourages young people to pursue a career in STEM. FIRST is for children ages 4-18 and divides members into teams to conduct research, fundraise, design, build and showcase their projects. 
UPCOMING WEBINAR
 
 
Feb. 8, 2023 | Tips for Completing the DiversityInc Top 50 Survey
Our free survey prep webinars, hosted by DiversityInc, address changes to the Top 50 assessment and data privacy, as well as responses to commonly asked questions.
IN CASE YOU MISSED IT
 
 
DACA Recipients Now Eligible for PhD Project Membership
Membership through The PhD Project is now available for Deferred Action for Childhood Arrival (DACA) recipients. Established in 1994, the PhD Project is a non-profit organization working to help make the academic and business worlds more diverse. 
 
5 Biggest News Stories of the Week: January 20
As the saying goes, the news never stops — but there’s a lot of it out there, and all of it doesn’t always pertain to our readers. In this weekly news roundup, we’ll cover the top news stories that matter most to our diversity focused audience.

subject: Meet Leaders in DEI at the Feb. 16 Breakfast Club
body:
Tara Cooper, equity, diversity and inclusion strategist at OpenSesame is the latest expert to join the panel discussion.
 
A Marathon, Not a Sprint: Examining the DEI Journey
 
Thursday, February 16, at 11 a.m. ET
 
Chief Learning Officer will host its first Breakfast Club of 2023 next month: "A Marathon, Not a Sprint: Examining the DEI Journey." Tara Cooper, equity, diversity and inclusion strategist at OpenSesame, is the latest expert to join the panel discussion.
 
Tara has over 20 years of experience addressing issues of equity, diversity and inclusion. She has worked collaboratively with organizations to build skills, strategies and capacity to advance and sustain equity and inclusion at every level of the organization. In coaching leaders, the focus is cultural awareness and growth mindset, personal leadership practice, resource alignment, policy and community engagement. Through equity audits, strategic planning, coaching and professional development, Tara creates opportunities for sustainable change — demonstrated in policy and practice, equitable hiring and retention strategies, and diverse community and stakeholder engagement. In addition to her professional experience in advancing equity, she also holds a master’s degree in intercultural communications and is completing her doctorate in adult learning and leadership.
 
Learn more from Tara and other thought leaders as they discuss learning and development’s level of involvement and influence on many organization’s DEI strategy by joining us February 16!

subject: Welcome to Chief Learning Officer! Let’s Get Started.
body:
You now have access to our wide variety of content, all of which is crafted to help you advance within the learning and development industry.
 
Dear Ashton, 
 
Welcome to Chief Learning Officer!
 
You now have access to our wide variety of content, all of which is crafted to help you advance within the learning and development industry. With a keen focus on topics that are constantly influencing the progression and direction of L&D, such as leadership development, measurement, enterprise education and more, we are pleased to play a role in your professional journey.
 
Here’s a little more about who we are and what we’re up to:
 
Who We Are
Chief Learning Officer is dedicated to serving as a platform and community for C-suite and senior-level learning and development professionals to connect and advance in the profession and their careers. We are by CLOs, for CLOs.
 
Events
Upcoming
Breakfast Club
: In this recently-reformatted series, we showcase expert learning and development professionals who are working to strengthen the link between learning and development and business strategy. Speakers are strategically hand-selected to ensure great knowledge of each event’s unique topic.
2023 CLO Symposium: We will return to in-person next year for the 2023 CLO Symposium, taking place October 16-18 at the gorgeous Rancho Bernardo Inn in San Diego, California, exploring the theme, "All Eyes on the Future: Building a Culture of Lifelong Learning." 
Registration is now open
.
Voices of CLO Podcast
: CLO hosts a bi-monthly podcast featuring learning and development movers and shakers sharing their stories, successes and setbacks and what's top of mind as we move forward into the future of learning and work.
Webinars
: Web events are the perfect way to freshen up on the latest workplace topics while gaining new ideas and insight into how those facing similar challenges are addressing them.
Recent
2022 CLO Symposium
: If you missed our biggest event of the year, we’re pleased to share that it's now available on-demand and can be accessed at any time. Watch, rewatch and/or share your favorite sessions from any of our keynote speakers and L&D experts now, and relive our most popular event at your convenience.
 
Trusted Content
You will find fresh content posted daily on 
chieflearningofficer.com
, brought to you by our award-winning editorial staff and reputable contributors. Check back regularly for new articles, or wait for the CLO Digest to hit your inbox every Monday, Wednesday and Friday.
 
Membership Details
Now that you’re subscribed to our emails, consider joining as a member! Members gain access to industry-leading research and benchmarking reports, exclusive access to members-only webinars and events, member-exclusive biannual print magazine and guaranteed early bird pricing + an extra $200 off your CLO Symposium registration. 
Get more details here
.
 
Follow Us
Stay current with upcoming events, the latest stories, exciting awards programs and more by following us on any of our active channels.
 
 
 
 
 
Thank you again for your support. 
We’re pleased to welcome you to our community!
Sincerely,
The Chief Learning Officer Team
